title: 2 Kings Chapter 13 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 2 Kings chapter 13 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 2 Kings Chapter 13 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 2 Kings Chapter 13.

questions.question: Who began to reign over Israel in Samaria in the three and twentieth year of Joash king of Judah?
questions.correctAnswer: Jehoahaz
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:1 states that Jehoahaz the son of Jehu began to reign over Israel in Samaria in that year.

questions.question: What kind of actions did Jehoahaz do in the sight of the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: Evil
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:2 says Jehoahaz did that which was evil in the sight of the LORD.

questions.question: Who oppressed Israel during Jehoahaz’s reign according to 2 Kings 13?
questions.correctAnswer: Hazael king of Syria
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:3 states that the LORD delivered Israel into the hand of Hazael king of Syria and Benhadad his son.

questions.question: True or False: Jehoahaz did not pray to the LORD when oppressed by the king of Syria.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:4 says Jehoahaz besought the LORD, and the LORD hearkened unto him.

questions.question: What did the LORD give Israel so they could go out from under the hand of the Syrians?
questions.correctAnswer: A saviour
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:5 says the LORD gave Israel a saviour to help them escape the Syrians.

questions.question: How many horsemen did Jehoahaz have left after the Syrians destroyed much of Israel’s army?
questions.correctAnswer: Fifty
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:7 states that only fifty horsemen remained to Jehoahaz.

questions.question: Who reigned in Israel after Jehoahaz died?
questions.correctAnswer: Joash
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:9 says Joash, the son of Jehoahaz, reigned after Jehoahaz died.

questions.question: How many years did Joash reign over Israel in Samaria?
questions.correctAnswer: Sixteen years
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:10 states Joash reigned sixteen years.

questions.question: True or False: Joash did what was good in the sight of the LORD and turned away from the sins of Jeroboam.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:11 says Joash did evil and did not depart from the sins of Jeroboam.

questions.question: What did Joash call Elisha when he wept over him?
options: O my father, my father, the chariot of Israel, and the horsemen thereof
questions.correctAnswer: O my father, my father, the chariot of Israel, and the horsemen thereof
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:14 records Joash calling Elisha by this title.

questions.question: What did Elisha instruct Joash to take when he was sick?
questions.correctAnswer: Bow and arrows
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:15 says Elisha told Joash to take bow and arrows.

questions.question: Complete the verse from 2 Kings 13:17: 'The arrow of the LORD'S ________, and the arrow of deliverance from Syria.'
questions.correctAnswer: deliverance
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:17 uses the phrase 'The arrow of the LORD'S deliverance.'

questions.question: How many times did Joash strike the ground with the arrows as Elisha commanded?
questions.correctAnswer: Three times
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:18 states Joash smote the ground three times.

questions.question: True or False: Elisha was pleased that Joash struck the ground only three times with the arrows.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:19 says Elisha was wroth because Joash should have struck five or six times.

questions.question: What miraculous event happened when a man was buried and his body touched Elisha’s bones?
options: The man revived and stood up
questions.correctAnswer: The man revived and stood up
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:21 describes a man reviving after touching Elisha’s bones.

medium.title: 2 Kings Chapter 13 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 2 Kings Chapter 13 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with repeated sin and asks how to remain faithful. Based on 2 Kings 13, what biblical truth would you share about perseverance and obedience?
options: Persist in prayer and seek God's help despite ongoing struggles.
Ignore past sins and focus only on future actions.
Rely on your own strength to overcome sin without God's help.
questions.correctAnswer: Persist in prayer and seek God's help despite ongoing struggles.
questions.explanation: Jehoahaz and Jehoash continued in the sins of Jeroboam (2 Kings 13:2, 13:11), yet Jehoahaz besought the LORD and God hearkened to him (2 Kings 13:4). This teaches us to persist in prayer and trust God even when we struggle.

questions.question: How does 2 Kings 13 teach us about trusting God during oppression or trials?
options: Trust God to deliver you and act on His promises.
Give up hope because oppression is permanent.
Seek alliances with worldly powers instead of God.
Ignore the oppression and pretend it does not exist.
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God to deliver you and act on His promises.
questions.explanation: Jehoahaz prayed to the LORD because of Syrian oppression, and God gave Israel a savior to deliver them (2 Kings 13:4-5). This encourages trust in God's deliverance during trials.

questions.question: What does the interaction between Elisha and King Joash teach about humility and obedience in leadership?
options: Obey God's instructions fully to receive full blessing.
Partial obedience is sufficient to please God.
Leaders should act independently of God's guidance.
Disregard God's word if it seems difficult.
questions.correctAnswer: Obey God's instructions fully to receive full blessing.
questions.explanation: Joash struck the ground three times instead of five or six, and Elisha was angry because incomplete obedience limited the victory over Syria (2 Kings 13:18-19). This teaches leaders to obey God fully.

questions.question: A believer is concerned about God's faithfulness despite their failures. What truth does 2 Kings 13 reveal about God's grace and covenant faithfulness?
options: God shows compassion because of His covenant with the patriarchs.
God only helps those who never sin.
God punishes without mercy when people fail.
God's covenant is conditional on perfect obedience.
questions.correctAnswer: God shows compassion because of His covenant with the patriarchs.
questions.explanation: Though Israel sinned, the LORD was gracious and compassionate because of His covenant with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, not casting them away (2 Kings 13:23).

questions.question: From Jehoash's reclaiming cities from Benhadad, what can we learn about perseverance and faithful work in facing opposition?
options: Repeated faithful efforts yield restoration and victory.
Giving up after initial failures is wise.
Rely only on human strength without God.
questions.correctAnswer: Repeated faithful efforts yield restoration and victory.
questions.explanation: Jehoash beat Benhadad three times and recovered cities (2 Kings 13:25), showing perseverance in faithful work brings success over opposition.

questions.question: How does 2 Kings 13 illustrate the importance of prayer in leadership?
options: Jehoahaz prayed to the LORD and received help against oppression.
Leaders should rely only on military power.
Leaders should not seek God's guidance.
questions.correctAnswer: Jehoahaz prayed to the LORD and received help against oppression.
questions.explanation: Jehoahaz besought the LORD, and God hearkened to his prayer, giving Israel relief (2 Kings 13:4-5), emphasizing prayer's vital role in godly leadership.

questions.question: True or False: Both Jehoahaz and Jehoash fully abandoned the sins of Jeroboam during their reigns.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Both kings did evil and did not depart from the sins of Jeroboam (2 Kings 13:2, 13:11), showing ongoing disobedience despite God's mercy.

questions.question: True or False: The man who touched Elisha's bones was revived, illustrating the power associated with God's prophet.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: When a man was cast into Elisha's sepulcher and touched his bones, he revived and stood up (2 Kings 13:21), showing God's power through His prophet.

questions.question: How does 2 Kings 13 teach about the importance of remembering and honoring spiritual mentors?
options: Joash wept over Elisha and called him 'my father,' showing respect and gratitude.
Ignore mentors after they pass away.
Spiritual mentors are not important in leadership.
Only kings deserve honor, not prophets.
questions.correctAnswer: Joash wept over Elisha and called him 'my father,' showing respect and gratitude.
questions.explanation: Joash honored Elisha deeply (2 Kings 13:14), teaching the value of honoring spiritual mentors and their role in our lives.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to give up on prayer during hardship. Based on 2 Kings 13, what encouragement would you give?
options: Prayer can bring relief even when circumstances seem hopeless.
Hardships prove God is not listening.
Stop praying and rely on human help only.
questions.correctAnswer: Prayer can bring relief even when circumstances seem hopeless.
questions.explanation: Jehoahaz prayed amid oppression, and the LORD gave Israel a savior, showing prayer's power even in difficult times (2 Kings 13:4-5).

questions.question: What practical lesson about stewardship and faithful service can be drawn from Joash's military victories in 2 Kings 13?
options: Faithful effort in service leads to reclaiming what was lost.
Avoid conflict to maintain peace at all costs.
Ignore enemies and hope problems resolve themselves.
Rely on others to do the hard work.
questions.correctAnswer: Faithful effort in service leads to reclaiming what was lost.
questions.explanation: Joash recovered cities taken by the enemy through repeated battles (2 Kings 13:25), encouraging faithful service and perseverance.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Elisha called Joash 'O my father, my father, the ______ of Israel, and the horsemen thereof.'
questions.correctAnswer: chariot
questions.explanation: Elisha referred to Joash as 'the chariot of Israel, and the horsemen thereof,' symbolizing strength and leadership (2 Kings 13:14).

questions.question: How does 2 Kings 13 teach us about the consequences of incomplete obedience?
options: Incomplete obedience results in limited blessing and victory.
Partial obedience is always rewarded fully.
Obedience is unnecessary if intentions are good.
questions.correctAnswer: Incomplete obedience results in limited blessing and victory.
questions.explanation: Joash smote the ground only three times instead of five or six, and Elisha said this limited Israel's conquest (2 Kings 13:18-19), showing consequences of incomplete obedience.

questions.question: Based on 2 Kings 13, how should we respond to God’s discipline and correction?
options: Respond with repentance and renewed faith.
Ignore it and continue as before.
questions.correctAnswer: Respond with repentance and renewed faith.
questions.explanation: Though Israel was disciplined by Syria due to sin (2 Kings 13:3, 22), God’s compassion remained, inviting repentance and trust (2 Kings 13:23).

questions.question: What does 2 Kings 13 reveal about God's covenant and His patience with His people?
options: God had compassion and did not destroy Israel because of His covenant.
God immediately destroyed Israel for their sins.
God’s covenant is based on human perfection.
God’s covenant allows unlimited sin without consequence.
questions.correctAnswer: God had compassion and did not destroy Israel because of His covenant.
questions.explanation: Despite Israel’s sin, the LORD showed grace and kept His covenant with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob (2 Kings 13:23), demonstrating His patience.

hard.title: 2 Kings Chapter 13 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 2 Kings Chapter 13.

questions.question: Who began to reign over Israel in Samaria in the twenty-third year of Joash king of Judah and reigned for seventeen years?
questions.correctAnswer: Jehoahaz son of Jehu
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:1 states that Jehoahaz son of Jehu began to reign in the twenty-third year of Joash king of Judah and reigned seventeen years.

questions.question: What repeated sin did Jehoahaz commit that is also associated with Jeroboam son of Nebat?
questions.correctAnswer: Idolatry with groves and calves
questions.explanation: Verses 2 and 6 indicate Jehoahaz did evil as Jeroboam son of Nebat did, including the presence of a grove in Samaria, which symbolizes idolatry.

questions.question: Which kings oppressed Israel during Jehoahaz’s reign, according to this chapter?
questions.correctAnswer: Hazael and Benhadad
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:3 states that the LORD delivered Israel into the hands of Hazael king of Syria and his son Benhadad during Jehoahaz’s reign.

questions.question: What military resources did Jehoahaz retain after Syrian oppression?
options: Fifty horsemen, ten chariots, and ten thousand footmen
One hundred horsemen, twenty chariots, and five thousand footmen
Ten horsemen, five chariots, and twenty thousand footmen
Seventy horsemen, fifteen chariots, and twelve thousand footmen
questions.correctAnswer: Fifty horsemen, ten chariots, and ten thousand footmen
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:7 details Jehoahaz was left with only fifty horsemen, ten chariots, and ten thousand footmen due to Syrian destruction.

questions.question: Who succeeded Jehoahaz as king of Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: Joash son of Jehoahaz
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:9 confirms that after Jehoahaz died, his son Joash reigned in his place.

questions.question: How long did Jehoash son of Jehoahaz reign over Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: Sixteen years
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:10 specifies Jehoash reigned sixteen years in Samaria.

questions.question: What was the nature of Joash’s conduct during his reign?
options: He did evil and followed Jeroboam’s sins
He was righteous and removed idols
He allied with Judah to defeat Syria
questions.correctAnswer: He did evil and followed Jeroboam’s sins
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:11 states Joash did evil in the sight of the LORD, continuing the sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat.

questions.question: Which king of Judah did Joash fight against according to the chronicles mentioned?
questions.correctAnswer: Amaziah
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:12 references Joash’s might in fighting against Amaziah king of Judah as recorded in the chronicles.

questions.question: What symbolic item did Elisha give to King Joash before his death?
questions.correctAnswer: Bow and arrows
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:15 explains Elisha instructed Joash to take bow and arrows as a symbol of the LORD’s deliverance.

questions.question: What did Elisha command Joash to do with the arrows, and what was the prophetic significance?
options: Shoot the east window; arrows symbolize deliverance from Syria
Throw arrows to the west; arrows symbolize defeat of Moab
Hide arrows in the temple; arrows symbolize protection of Israel
Break arrows on the ground; arrows symbolize the end of war
questions.correctAnswer: Shoot the east window; arrows symbolize deliverance from Syria
questions.explanation: In 2 Kings 13:17, Elisha tells Joash to open the east window and shoot the arrow, signifying the LORD's deliverance from Syria.

questions.question: How many times did Joash strike the ground with the arrows, and what was Elisha’s reaction?
options: Thrice; Elisha was angry because he should have struck five or six times
Twice; Elisha was pleased with the result
Once; Elisha rebuked him for not striking more times
questions.correctAnswer: Thrice; Elisha was angry because he should have struck five or six times
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:18-19 says Joash struck thrice and stopped, which made Elisha angry because more strikes would have meant complete victory.

questions.question: What miraculous event occurred involving Elisha’s bones after his death?
options: A dead man revived upon touching Elisha’s bones
The bones emitted a bright light
A prophet was raised up from the bones
questions.correctAnswer: A dead man revived upon touching Elisha’s bones
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:21 records that a man was revived when his body touched Elisha’s bones, illustrating Elisha’s continuing power after death.

questions.question: True or False: Despite Israel’s sins, the LORD showed compassion and did not utterly cast them away because of His covenant with the patriarchs.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:23 affirms that the LORD was gracious and compassionate to Israel because of His covenant with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.

questions.question: How many times did Joash defeat Benhadad son of Hazael and recover Israel’s cities?
questions.correctAnswer: Three times
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:25 states Joash beat Benhadad three times, recovering the cities taken from Israel.

questions.question: What is the typological significance of Joash’s lament over Elisha as 'my father, my father, the chariot of Israel, and the horsemen thereof'?
options: It reflects Elisha as a spiritual protector and leader of Israel’s military strength
It signifies Joash's desire to ascend the throne of Judah
It alludes to Elisha’s lineage as a king of Israel
It symbolizes Joash’s mourning for lost chariots
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects Elisha as a spiritual protector and leader of Israel’s military strength
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:14 uses this metaphor to highlight Elisha’s role as a divine warrior figure, paralleling the chariot and horsemen as symbols of military power protected by prophetic authority.

theological.title: 2 Kings Chapter 13 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 2 Kings Chapter 13 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was the spiritual condition of Jehoahaz during his reign over Israel?
options: He did evil in the sight of the LORD, following the sins of Jeroboam
He faithfully followed the LORD and abolished idolatry
He was neutral and did not worship any gods
He rebuilt the temple of the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: He did evil in the sight of the LORD, following the sins of Jeroboam
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:2 clearly states that Jehoahaz did evil in the sight of the LORD and followed the sins of Jeroboam. This echoes the Old Testament teaching on human sinfulness and idolatry (e.g., Romans 3:23; Judges 2:11-13; Hosea 4:12-13; 1 Kings 14:16).

questions.question: How did God respond to Israel’s persistent sin during Jehoahaz’s reign?
options: He delivered them into the hand of Hazael king of Syria
He sent a prophet to rebuke them without judgment
He raised an army from Israel to defeat their enemies
questions.correctAnswer: He delivered them into the hand of Hazael king of Syria
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:3 explains that God’s anger was kindled against Israel and He delivered them into the hand of Hazael king of Syria. This illustrates God’s righteous judgment against sin (Psalm 7:11; Isaiah 10:5-6; Romans 1:18-20; Revelation 6:10-11).

questions.question: What action did Jehoahaz take in response to Israel’s oppression by Syria?
options: He besought the LORD, who hearkened to him
He formed an alliance with Syria
He ignored the oppression and continued sinning
He fled to Judah for protection
questions.correctAnswer: He besought the LORD, who hearkened to him
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:4 states that Jehoahaz besought the LORD and the LORD hearkened to him, showing the mercy and responsiveness of God to His people’s repentance (Joel 2:12-13; 2 Chronicles 7:14; Jeremiah 29:12-13; Psalm 34:17; 1 John 1:9).

questions.question: Despite God giving Israel a saviour to deliver them from the Syrians, what was Israel’s ongoing spiritual problem?
options: They did not depart from the sins of the house of Jeroboam
They rebuilt the altar of the LORD faithfully
They followed the Mosaic Law strictly
questions.correctAnswer: They did not depart from the sins of the house of Jeroboam
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:5-6 highlights that although God gave Israel a saviour, they persisted in the sins of Jeroboam. This illustrates human stubbornness in sin despite divine grace (Romans 1:21-22; Hebrews 3:12-13; Judges 2:17; Jeremiah 2:13; Ezekiel 14:6).

questions.question: What does the limited military strength left to Jehoahaz signify in a theological context?
options: The devastating consequences of sin and divine judgment on Israel
God’s blessing and increase in Israel’s power
The success of Israel’s military campaigns
questions.correctAnswer: The devastating consequences of sin and divine judgment on Israel
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:7 indicates that only a small remnant of Israel’s army remained due to Syrian oppression, symbolizing how sin leads to national weakness and judgment (Deuteronomy 28:15-68; Isaiah 1:5-7; Psalm 78:34-37; Jeremiah 25:9-11; Romans 6:23).

questions.question: How does the phrase ‘Jehoahaz slept with his fathers’ connect to biblical teaching on death and legacy?
options: It is a euphemism for death, indicating the continuation of the dynasty
It means he was taken to heaven without dying
It refers to his exile from the land
questions.correctAnswer: It is a euphemism for death, indicating the continuation of the dynasty
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:9 uses this phrase, common in Scripture to denote death while affirming the continuity of kingship and covenant promises (Genesis 25:8; 1 Kings 2:10-11; Psalm 37:37; Hebrews 11:13-16; Revelation 14:13).

questions.question: What was the spiritual legacy of Jehoash, son of Jehoahaz, according to 2 Kings 13?
options: He did evil and did not depart from the sins of Jeroboam
He led Israel to repentance and righteousness
He abolished idolatry and rebuilt the temple
He formed an alliance with Judah for peace
questions.correctAnswer: He did evil and did not depart from the sins of Jeroboam
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:11 attests that Jehoash continued in evil ways, showing the persistent problem of covenant unfaithfulness despite God’s mercy (Judges 10:6; 1 Kings 12:30-33; Romans 7:15-20; Ezekiel 20:30-31; Hebrews 3:12).

questions.question: What significant messianic title does Joash use when he weeps over the sick Elisha?
options: "O my father, my father, the chariot of Israel, and the horsemen thereof"
"My brother, the prophet of the LORD"
questions.correctAnswer: "O my father, my father, the chariot of Israel, and the horsemen thereof"
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:14 records Joash’s lament using this phrase, symbolizing Elisha’s role as God’s divine warrior, a motif pointing forward to the Messiah as the LORD’s chariot and warrior (Psalm 20:7; 2 Samuel 6:17; Isaiah 66:15; Revelation 19:11-16; Zechariah 6:1-5).

questions.question: What does the symbolic act of shooting arrows eastward by Joash signify in its theological meaning?
options: The LORD’s deliverance from Syria and victory in battle
A ritual for rain and harvest
A declaration of peace with Syria
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD’s deliverance from Syria and victory in battle
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:17 explains that the arrow symbolizes the LORD’s deliverance and victory over Syria. This reflects biblical symbolism of arrows as instruments of God’s judgment or deliverance (Psalm 7:12-13; Isaiah 49:2; Ephesians 6:16; Habakkuk 3:9; Revelation 6:2).

questions.question: Why was Elisha angry when Joash struck the ground only three times with the arrows?
options: Because he should have struck five or six times to fully consume Syria
Because he struck too many times
Because he refused to strike at all
Because he struck with the wrong hand
questions.correctAnswer: Because he should have struck five or six times to fully consume Syria
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:19 reveals Elisha’s anger due to Joash’s limited obedience, teaching that incomplete obedience limits God’s blessings (1 Samuel 15:22-23; Deuteronomy 28:1-2; Hebrews 11:6; James 2:17; Revelation 3:15-16).

questions.question: What miraculous event occurred when a dead man touched the bones of Elisha?
options: The man revived and stood on his feet
A plague struck the people nearby
questions.correctAnswer: The man revived and stood on his feet
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:21 describes a resurrection miracle through Elisha’s bones, demonstrating God’s power over death and a foreshadowing of resurrection in Christ (John 11:43-44; Romans 6:4-5; Ezekiel 37:1-10; Acts 9:40; Revelation 20:6).

questions.question: What attribute of God is revealed in His continued compassion toward Israel despite their sin?
options: God’s rejection of the nation entirely
questions.correctAnswer: God’s covenant faithfulness and mercy
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:23 shows God’s grace and respect for His covenant with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, highlighting divine mercy and faithfulness (Exodus 34:6-7; Lamentations 3:22-23; Hebrews 6:13-18; Psalm 89:34-37; 2 Timothy 2:13).

questions.question: How many times did Jehoash defeat Benhadad and recover cities from Syria?
questions.correctAnswer: Three times
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:25 states that Joash beat Benhadad three times and recovered the cities. This shows partial deliverance from oppression, illustrating God’s patience and progressive victory (Judges 3:28; 2 Chronicles 20:22-23; Romans 8:37; Revelation 12:11; Psalm 44:5).

questions.question: What does the presence of groves in Samaria during Jehoahaz's reign indicate about Israel's religious practices?
options: Continued idolatry and departure from true worship
Strict adherence to the Mosaic Law
Exclusive worship of Yahweh in the temple
questions.correctAnswer: Continued idolatry and departure from true worship
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:6 mentions the grove in Samaria, symbolic of idolatrous worship practices forbidden by God (Deuteronomy 12:2-4; Judges 6:25-32; Jeremiah 3:6-10; Ezekiel 8:14-16; 1 Corinthians 10:14).

questions.question: What theological lesson can be drawn from the limited military forces left to Jehoahaz by the king of Syria?
options: Human strength is insufficient without God’s blessing
All nations prosper regardless of their sins
Peace is achieved through alliances with enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Human strength is insufficient without God’s blessing
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 13:7 shows the decimation of Israel’s forces due to divine judgment, teaching that true deliverance and power come from God, not human might (Psalm 20:7; Isaiah 31:1; Zechariah 4:6; John 15:5; Philippians 4:13).
